questions.question: Question 1: The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes all of the following symptoms except:
questions.explanation:
The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes the following symptoms: • Headache • Profuse sweating • Palpitation (due to tachycardia) Hypertension is the most predominant sign of pheochromocytoma. Though intermittent 
hypertension is a classical feature, sustained hypertension is also common.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following would you not see in a patient with pheochromocytoma?
questions.explanation:
Hypercalcemia is seen in patients with pheochromocytoma, not hypocalcemia. This is due to the 
production of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) by the tumor.

questions.question:
Question 3: In a patient with pheochromocytoma, which of the following clinical features is least likely to 
be present?
questions.explanation:
Polyuria, not oliguria is seen in patients with pheochromocytoma. Excess catecholamine levels in this condition can cause polyuria and polydipsia due 
to hyperglycemia.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following is an associated finding that can be seen in patients with 
pheochromocytoma?
questions.explanation:
Café au lait spots are seen in neurofibromatosis 1, which is a pheochromocytoma-associated 
syndrome. Pheochromocytoma-associated syndromes include the following: • Neurofibromatosis type 1 • Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 • Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome • Paraganglioma syndrome

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following parameters can help you diagnose a patient with a malignant 
pheochromocytoma?
questions.explanation:
Malignant pheochromocytoma refers to tumors that have undergone metastasis to lymph nodes 
or distant sites. 137 
Sold by @itachibot They are histologically and biochemically the same as benign ones. Hence, typical histological 
criteria like cellular atypia, mitotic spindles, and capsular invasion are insufficient to 
confirm malignancy in pheochromocytomas.

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following catecholamines would be elevated in a patient with extra-adrenal 
pheochromocytoma?
questions.explanation:
Norepinephrine is exclusively secreted in patients with extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma. The PNMT (phenylethanolamine-N-methyl transferase) enzyme converts norepinephrine to 
epinephrine. This enzyme is absent in extra-adrenal sites. Hence, extra-adrenal 
pheochromocytomas secrete only norepinephrine and cannot secrete epinephrine. On the other hand, adrenal pheochromocytomas can secrete norepinephrine, epinephrine, 
and dopamine in varying amounts depending on the PNMT levels in the tumor. Extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas or catecholamine-secreting paragangliomas are most 
commonly found in the abdomen. They commonly arise from the organ of Zuckerkandl.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 31-year-old woman is rushed to the ED with a severe headache and vomiting. Past history 
includes a total thyroidectomy for thyroid cancer 3 months ago. Her BP is 200/100 mm Hg 
and pulse is 110/min. On examination, a marfanoid habitus is noted along with the findings 
shown. Which of the following is likely to be predominantly elevated? 133 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario with a history of thyroid cancer (likely medullary carcinoma) and the image 
showing mucosal neuromas points towards MEN2B syndrome. Her current presentation is 
suggestive of a pheochromocytoma. She is likely to have predominantly elevated levels 
of epinephrine and its metabolite, metanephrine. This is due to the higher expression of the PNMT enzyme associated with the mutations in MEN2 
syndromes (both 2A and 2B). The higher levels of epinephrine result in a more symptomatic 
presentation. In contrast, low PNMT expression is seen in von-Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome. This leads to a 
predominant elevation of norepinephrine and normetanephrine levels. It is less symptomatic 
compared to MEN2 syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 8: In a suspected case of pheochromocytoma, which of the following would you avoid while 
making a diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Biopsy and FNAC should be avoided in patients with pheochromocytoma, as it is a highly vascular 
tumor. CT and MRI have similar sensitivity but T2-weighted MRI with gadolinium contrast is the optimal 
test for diagnosis. MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) scintigraphy can be used to localize the 
tumor if both CT and MRI are negative. Genetic testing may be performed as nearly 40% of the tumors are associated with familial 
syndromes like VHL, neurofibromatosis, and MEN2. Note: In cases of malignant pheochromocytoma, biopsy may be indicated to confirm adrenal 
gland metastasis in other sites. 138 
Sold by @itachibot

Question 9: A middle-aged male patient is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of palpitations, 
headaches, and profuse sweating. He was found to have elevated blood pressure readings on 
multiple occasions over the past 2 months. Which of the following tests has the highest 
sensitivity and specificity for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.explanation:

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following is the best method for detecting and localization of tumors associated 
with pheochromocytomas?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, the fluorodopa-PET scan is the best method for detecting and 
localization of tumors associated with pheochromocytoma. If biochemical testing for pheochromocytoma is positive, an abdominal MRI must be performed 
first. If MRI is negative or if multiple tumors are suspected, the tumor can be localized by 
performing one of the following investigations: • 68 Ga-DOTATATE PET scan - most sensitive, gold standard • Fluorodopa and 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) PET scans - 97% sensitive • MIBG scintigraphy - least sensitive (94%)

questions.question:
Question 11: A 45-year-old man presented with recurrent episodes of headache, palpitations, and sweating. 
His blood pressure at presentation was 180/100 mm Hg. Further testing revealed elevated 
urinary metanephrines. CT abdomen showed a right adrenal mass. What is the drug of choice 
for the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. The drug of choice to control blood 
pressure prior to surgery is oral phenoxybenzamine at 0.5–4 mg/kg of body weight. It is a 
non-specific -blocker and is preferred due to its long action (3-4 days). 139 
Sold by @itachibot Other -blockers like oral prazosin and intravenous phentolamine have a shorter duration of 
action and can be used to manage paroxysms. IV phentolamine is also used for intra-operative 
management of BP. -blockers are usually given for 7 days. Following this, -blockers are started, usually 2-3 days 
preoperatively. -blockers should never be started first because blockade of vasodilatory 
peripheral -receptors with unopposed -receptor stimulation can lead to a further elevation in 
blood pressure. (Mnemonic: A before B)

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following should not be used for the initial management, in a patient with 
pheochromocytoma?
questions.explanation:
Beta-blockers like atenolol should never be used as the initial drug or alone in the management of 
pheochromocytoma. They must be given only after adequate alpha blockade has been established. Blocking 
beta-receptors may cause unopposed stimulation of alpha-receptors, precipitating a hypertensive 
crisis. Option A: Prazosin is an alpha-blocker. Option C: Nitroprusside can be used in case of hypertensive emergencies. Option D: Metyrosine inhibits catecholamine synthesis. It can be used when other agents have 
been ineffective.

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following is not a part of Averbuch’s chemotherapy protocol? 135 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Vinblastine is not included in Averbuch’s chemotherapy protocol for the treatment of malignant 
pheochromocytoma.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient is diagnosed with malignant pheochromocytoma. Which of the following is used to 
treat this condition?

options.d: It is associated with coronary heart disease

questions.explanation:
131I-MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) is used for the treatment of malignant pheochromocytoma. Malignant pheochromocytomas occur in 10% of cases and are histologically and biochemically the 
same as benign ones. The diagnosis of malignant pheochromocytoma is based on documentation 
of metastatic disease. The treatment of choice is nuclear medicine therapy with any of the 
following: • 131I-MIBG at 200-mCi doses at monthly intervals (3-6 cycles) • DOTATOC (a somatostatin receptor analog) labeled with radioactive lutetium or yttrium Chemotherapy can also be given according to Averbuch's protocol. Note: 123I-MIBG and Gallium-DOTATATE are used for imaging. 140 
Sold by @itachibot Cushing's Syndrome
